image.altText: Jasmina, woman in pink sihrt smiling, holding a baby wearing a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary back-up plan.

title.children: 'They need an oven and I have to cook it': Why Jasmina, 52, gave birth to her grandson

image.altText: A colourful abstract map, with hues ranging through a red to blue spectrum.

items.synopsis: Canberrans are sometimes accused of being out of touch and different from other Australians — and this socio-economic data shows they are.

title.children: The 'Canberra bubble' is very real. Here's the data that proves it

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin – for the moment at least – is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin needs this man more than anyone else — until the moment he ceases to be of use

image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: The crew of the Blythe Star were thought lost at sea. So why did they stumble out of a forest?

image.altText: Composite image of a Korean man smiling and an Australian woman smiling.

items.synopsis: As South Korea edges closer to being solely powered by renewables come 2050, the manufacturing industries of Australia's third-largest trading partner believe hydrogen gas is the answer to help reach its target.

title.children: Korea's demand for Australian hydrogen has never been higher. Is it the start of a new mining boom?

image.altText: A line stretches back as far as the eye can see outside Centrelink.

items.synopsis: You can define a "recession" in different ways. Are we experiencing one now? asks Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What is a recession? Are we experiencing one now?

image.altText: Recep Tayyip Erdogan looks down in front of a black background while standing next to the Turkish flag

items.synopsis: Türkiye appears headed for a run-off presidential election, with the parties of both Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and opposition rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu both claiming the lead.

title.children: Türkiye run-off election likely as both President Erdoğan​​​​​​​ and opposition leader claim lead

image.altText: Three mugshots of three separate men. The first has tattoos on his face. The second has a beard. The third has darker skin.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Manhunt for three escaped prisoners, and Paddington and the Queen win a BAFTA. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian golf star Jason Day has broken a five-year PGA Tour title drought with an emotion-charged Mother's Day victory at the $US9.5 million ($14.3 million) AT & T Byron Nelson Championship in Texas. A year after losing his mum Dening to cancer and tumbling outside the top 100, Day denied Scottie Scheffler the chance to return to world number one in a tense shootout at TPC Craig Ranch. In a poignant tribute, Day's caddy sported a bib with his mother's birth name Adenil and the former world number one honoured her memory with his first tournament win since the 2018 Farmers Insurance Open .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia's Jason Day breaks five-year PGA Tour title drought

props.alt: A man swings a golf club while wearing a cap

children.content: (AP)
Australian golf star Jason Day has broken a five-year PGA Tour title drought with
an emotion-charged Mother's Day victory
at the $US9.5 million ($14.3 million) AT
T Byron Nelson Championship in Texas.
A year after losing his mum Dening to cancer and tumbling outside the top 100, Day denied Scottie Scheffler the chance to return to world number one in a tense shootout at TPC Craig Ranch.
In a poignant tribute, Day's caddy sported a bib with his mother's birth name Adenil and the former world number one honoured her memory with
his first tournament win since the 2018 Farmers Insurance Open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The BAFTA TV awards have wrapped up in London, with the likes of The Traitors, Derry Girls, Bad Sisters and even Paddington Bear taking home awards for the best in British TV. Kate Winslet won the BAFTA for leading actress for her role in I Am Ruth, while Anne-Marie Duff won supporting actress for her portrayal of Grace Williams in drama series Bad Sisters. Ben Whishaw won leading actor for his portrayal of Adam Kay in autobiographical drama This is Going to Hurt, while Adeel Akhtar won the BAFTA for supporting actor for his role in the crime drama Sherwood. Derry Girls won in scripted comedy, with Sister Michael actress Siobhán McSweeney winning for female performance in a comedy programme. Entertainment performance was won by Claudia Winkleman for The Traitors, which won for reality and constructed factual. But the memorable moment award, the only award voted for by the public, was won by Paddington and Queen Elizabeth II's Party at the Palace sketch for the late monarch's jubilee … … and Paddington is pretty excited about it. You can see the full list of winners and nominees at the Baftas website .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queen Elizabeth II and Paddington are among the BAFTA TV award winners

children.content: The BAFTA TV awards have wrapped up in London, with the likes of The Traitors, Derry Girls, Bad Sisters and even Paddington Bear taking home awards for the best in British TV.
Kate Winslet won the BAFTA for leading actress for her role in
I Am Ruth
, while Anne-Marie Duff won supporting actress for her portrayal of Grace Williams in drama series
Bad Sisters

props.alt: Kate Winslet, winner of the leading actress BAFTA for I Am Ruth, holds up the award next to her head.

children.content: Kate Winslet, winner of the leading actress BAFTA for I Am Ruth.
(Reuters: Maja Smiejkowska)
Ben Whishaw won leading actor for his portrayal of Adam Kay in autobiographical drama
This is Going to Hurt
, while Adeel Akhtar won the BAFTA for supporting actor for his role in the crime drama
Sherwood
Derry Girls
won in scripted comedy, with Sister Michael actress Siobhán McSweeney winning for female performance in a comedy programme.
Entertainment performance was won by Claudia Winkleman for
The Traitors
, which won for reality and constructed factual.
But the memorable moment award, the only award voted for by the public, was won by Paddington and Queen Elizabeth II's
Party at the Palace
sketch for the late monarch's jubilee …
… and Paddington is pretty excited about it.
You can see the full list of winners and nominees at the
Baftas website

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday. The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane. Authorities are now on the hunt for Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28. Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Manhunt underway after three men escape a Queensland prison

props.alt: Three mug shots of men, one with a beard and one with tattoos on his face

children.content: (AAP: Queensland Police)
A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday.
The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane.
Authorities are now on the hunt for
Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28

Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand

Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg

Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm
Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.
